reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've waited a long, long time for this game to come out on Steam. Sure, it's still incomplete; but it's here nonetheless. I know that some people are still complaining about the graphics being ten years old; but if you think about it, Black Mesa originated as a mod for Half-Life 2. Screw the graphics, look at the engine! When you sprint, it actually looks like you're sprinting! Such a feature was never introduced to Half-Life. There are different view models for the player arms in multiplayer, unlike in Half-Life 2 Deathmatch where your arms are still from Gordon Freeman's HEV Suit. Also, how your HUD starts appearing when you start wearing the HEV Suit. EPIC!!!

I'll give this game a 9/10. I would give it a 10/10 if it had any of the Xen levels. Thankfully, Xen will not be presented in a DLC. The makers of Black Mesa have confirmed that Xen will be introduced in the game's final update. Otherwise, yeah, my rating would be lower if it was going to be a DLC.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nStill Half Life. Still immersive and atmospheric as hell. Goes to show just how inspired the original was if it's still able to captivate me years on. I quickly found myseld drifting back into the game's clutches, paying attention to the tiniest sounds as I navigated Black Mesa's hallways - something extremely few games manage to make me do after having played them for years, and especially when I've since started working in game development. I've been looking to replay the series, but having played the original several times over the years, I figured I'd wait until this 'remaster' to give it another go. I'm glad I did. The added level bits and characer interactions are welcome little distractions and don't take away from the experience or feel 'tacked on'; the guts are still the same old Half Life you know and love, just with a that shiny nice look provided by a fresh audio-visual coat of paint. Freeman is still the same mute functional sociopath everyone fell in love with.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most people expect a replica of Half Life 1 - and hence compare this mod very critically with Half Life 1. If you think that way as well you might get disappointed. As some reviews already pointed out this is not exactly Half Life 1. It follows the general story line and sticks to the original map layouts wherever sensible and possible. But it still brings its own style. And as soon as you accept that this is a mod with its own style it's actually quite enjoyable.

One thing I (as a casual player) did not like is the difficulty which is solely generated by raising the number of enemies significantly (and - in my opinion - unnecessarily). Half Life (all of it) for me is first and foremost about the story telling. And when you play through HL2 and its two episodes with commentary on you really get a feel of the level in which that was done intentionally by Valve. This is where raw numbers of enemies don't make sense. A good balance does.

Generally: Play it. It's worth it! Wait for the Xen levels if you want a full game, this one still stops at the jump to Xen.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa brings back the original Half-Life campaign in a way far surpasing Valves own attempts to do so. What the dedicated mod team, now indie developers, have done is not simple port over the original assets with the adition of a physics engine and HD lighting, we're talking a full blown remake with its own quirks, pitfalls and soul.

If you've played the original as much as I have, you'll feel familiar with everything you see around you but be surprised when it deviates or tries something different. Usually for the better. If you're a new to the story and series, just sit back and enjoy yourself. You're in for one hell of a ride.

Definitely an inprovement over the original Black Mesa mod, and if they even just ported that onto steam it'd be worth the $20. Either way you try it you can't go wrong.

Twice I have found myself replaying large portions of a game due to an unrealiable auto-save system or my latest save not appearing upon booting the game, often time the auto-save aren't particulalry well thought out either. Some are close together, some far apart and some put in silly areas. One example being the time the game auto-saved me falling to my death.

Hopefully these things will be fixed soon enough, I can not stress that despite the minor issues the game feels fresh, fantastic and relevent again. Its a testement to the imagination and hard work of the guys involved as well as the Source 2 engine.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played the majority of Black Mesa Source before it came to early access, and I'm enjoying playing the current incarnation even more, being that it's more rounded out and has some great (and authentic) multiplayer. Some performance issues aside online, the game is running very smoothly and it is clear that the game is a labour of love by a dedicated team.

My only bone of contention, and it's arguable that I'm perhaps missing the point, is that in some ways the game doesn't quite go far enough in it's vision, or perhaps rather than it is at times inconsistent in it's execution. The approach, obviously, is to recreate, or 're-envision' Half-Life from beginning to end, using modern technology and methods that are more contemporary to gaming post 2000 (or even 2005). The result is a game that is not just visually familiar but one that plays very familiarly, for better and worse. Some of Half-Life's more irritating sections have been altered and streamlined, yet some are curiously left unaltered, issues intact. Something about this inconsistency speaks to the games origins as a mod by a team spread out geographically, with level designers with different ideas of what the game should be like spread out far and wide. The Sector C labs, for instance, have been extended and fleshed out with a great deal more detail, but this is more superficial, whereas the Office Complex unit has been edited and reshaped more substantially, to greater effect. Some of the original chapter's more bland areas are not just visually striking, but contain fresh secrets and nooks and crannies to explore, as well as some surprises, enemy wise. At the very least, the facelift is welcome, but at times it feels like the opportunity to really take the essence of Half-Life and build upon it is underused in favour of remaining faithful.

The game is still in development, of course. Xen is still absent, presumably because it was always going to be the most problematic chapter to rebuild in terms of making it actually enjoyable, this time around (it always was a bizarre end to the original Half-Life, tonally shifting entirely from intense combat to akward platforming mechanics and a really terrible boss fight at the end). I'm hoping the workshop features some other additions that allow other interpretations to be dropped into the single player experience as well as the welcome but predictable multiplayer remakes.

The multiplayer component, whilst suffering from performance issues at the moment (a few days after initial release), is a blast and really does take me back to the LAN party death-match sessions I would indulge in when I was fifteen and sixteen years old. The weapons all feel substantial and impactful, and the map design is first-rate.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access/Pre Zen Update

11hrs for £15 (so far).

Gameplay wise it hasn't changed too much from Half Life 1. So if you liked the original, chances are you'll like this.

There's been a few changes in level designs and I think the weapons have been slightly rebalanced, so don't expect a complete carbon copy of the original. Saying that, I liked most of the changes. Personally, I found some of the platforming sections annoying (as I did in the original - something I would have been happy if they had skipped recreating) and the bloody assassins are real pains, but getting past them gives the same sense of achievement. In that sense I enjoyed the game.

However, the big selling point, and the original point (from what I remember) of the mod, was to recreate Half Life with better graphics. And this is where the developers both succeed and fail. If this had been released a couple of years after Half Life 2, then I wouldn't have any reservations about recommending it. Unfortunately, the engine has aged (not as badly as some mind you), but its obvious that this engine is 11 years old. And it struggles to compete against more recent efforts. Saying that, its obvious that, in certain areas, the developers have put a lot of effort in, and the game looks absolutely amazing. I certainly paused in places to have a look around and enjoy the views. But, at this stage in development, that quality isn't consistent. And that's the problem. Its 2015, and at times, I would be hard pressed to tell the difference between this game and the original 17 year old game (yeah... that's made me feel old).

So its hard to recommend it, but I will. I loved the original, and this game has allowed me to revisit that world, but in a much prettier way.

Wonderfully recreation of Half-Life.
Think Half-Life with the engine of Half-Life 2. It's HL better than you remember; I felt like I was playing HL1 for the first time again.
It has the same story as HL1 but beyond that everything has been updated. New textures on EVERYTHING, new voice acting, new scripted events, new ENGINE.
The new textures make gameplay more immersive and the people look more like, well, people. The bullsquid is incredibly terrifying now. The voice acting has been redone and some new dialogue can be heard, especially from the new female scientists (I guess the EO complaints finally caught up with Lambda.)
There are new scripted events for enemy intros that really show off all the work the Crowbar Collective has put into this game. Most levels have been modified in small ways to use puzzle mechanics from 2HL2. Anyone who is a fan of the HL series will enjoy playing game as we wait for the next installmant in the HL franchise.
Pros:
-New Engine!
-HL2 mechanics-set enemies on fire, throw back grenades, crawling zombies
-New textures for EVERYTHING
-Voice acting redone and more dialogue from NPCs, female scientists.
-New enemy intros, attack styles, and sounds
-Most levels updated to feature puzzle mechanics from HL2
-Amazing gameplay!


Cons:
-As of writing this the entire game has not been completed yet; Xen levels not released.
-Some of the levels have ledges big enough to walk around/skip fights i.e. Surface Tension
-On the level Surface Tension" if you travel to the sublevel 'Ordnance Exterior'
date: leave and return you can be stuck in a loop of gameover explosions. Can set you back if you don't save.\n-Enemy AI seems more like NPCs always know where you are even-through walls. i.e. Tanks and Helicopters are always aimed and shooting at you even inside buildings."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa, the largely anticipated remake of one of the best first person shooter games of all time, certainly lives up to the standards of its predecessor. It was made by fans of the Half-Life franchise, and it is a very large project indeed. It originally started as a mod of Half-Life 2, but has now grown into a standalone game.

There are two versions of Black Mesa.
BMS 2012 (The mod version)
BMS 2015 (The Steam version)

BMS 2012 was released in 2012, as a mod that required Valve's free Source SDK base 2007 to run. It was a groundbreaking remake of the first Half-Life game's single player campaign, minus the final four chapters. After 8 years in development, it was worth the weight wait.

BMS 2015 was recently released, you guessed it, in 2015, on Steam. This version features updated graphics, new content, new voice acting, and an all new multiplayer experience, featuring free-for-all deathmatch and team deathmatch modes. The final four chapters have yet to be added, and I am very excited for them, as I have heard that they will be packed full of gameplay. People have complained about the $20 price tag, despite the fact that the developers that make up Crowbar Collective have stated long ago that they intended to sell the Steam version.

I am happy with the price, as the developers deserve to earn money for such a jaw-droppingly epic project. People also need to understand that it is in early access, so of course there will be problems that will ultimately be fixed. As a game, Black Mesa is very engaging in the departments of gameplay and story. As a remake, Black Mesa is truly beyond astounding. It reminds me so much of Half-Life, when it comes to the art style, the level design, and the (occasional) humor. The developers have added many nods to the Half-Life storyline that developed after the first game was released. And also, the Gman is as mysterious as ever.

10/10. Amazing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It was excellent as a mod. It's excellent as a game. I feel the price could be a bit lower, $15 seems like a more ideal starting point for anything running on the Source Engine at this point especially in Early Access when we're still waiting on Xen, but regardless, what this is is a finely crafted masterpiece that stands up there with official Valve games in presentation and quality. It also stands as an example of how I believe modders should be able to make money from their work, by starting off with a free base and using that to craft something that is genuinely retail quality, and going through official channels like Greenlight to become an official product with all that entails instead of the vaguely defined rules and assurances and horrible implementation of that disastrous Workshop incident with Skyrim.

If nothing else, buy this game as a statement of how mods turning into retail products is supposed to work, following the legacy of the likes of Counterstrike and Team Fortress and Red Orchestra. But better yet, buy it because it's just an awesome game, squeezing the best graphics seen yet out of the Source Engine with superb gameplay that fills a gap in the Half Life universe many gamers hadn't experienced due to Half Life 1 being before their time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An excellent retelling of the Half-Life story, which remains faithful where it counts but isn't afraid to make significant changes here and there. Not all of the changes are for the best, but many are, and none are severely damaging. Some of my favorite content is actually the most divergent from HL1, because it feels more like the all new HL game, which we've all been waiting for...

All in all it's incredible this was first created as a mod -- and it's more than worthy of sale as a standalone product.

I was hoping the Steam release would include Xen, which it doesn't, but the developers have made good on their promised polish so far, and given that those old Xen chapters arguably stand to benefit from overhaul, I can't wait to check them out when they're done.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Review:

Black Mesa, for those of you that don't know, is a complete remake of Half Life 1 by a small team of folks. When it comes down to remaking one of the best games of all time, it's a very high bar to set for yourself to even be acceptable in the gaming community, but I'll tell you, it was definitely accomplished. Triple A multimillion dollar games fall flat on their faces compared to this game. If you followed the developement of this game, you'll know there was several snags, and several delays with such a small team that was changing constantly over the past 8 or so years. When the free version released in 2012, it was a ton of fun, lacking the Xen levels, but it gave you a taste of what you were going to be getting when the finished product was here. So here's the steam release. If you played the free version, the first thing you'll notice is how much smoother and cleaner the game feels. The visuals have all been bumped up to probably being the prettiest source GAME let alone the prettiest source mod. When you got lost in half life for the first time, you experienced action, tension, and entertaining puzzles and sometimes fierce battles. Black Mesa succeeded completely in being able to bring this feeling out again. While feeling very familiar, every environment was brand new and designed brilliantly. I'd find myself normally know where to go thanks to playing the original so much, but there were also more than a couple moments where I'd get lost and have some minor issues progressing, but that's a good thing in my mind, taking an old game and making it challenging again. Certain aspects of Half life that got annoying or tedious have more or less been altered to make it quicker, more managable, and less hassle. For example, during the Power up" level

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa is a great game, I played through the mod many times and I bought this version mainly for the multiplayer, which did not disappoint.

The multiplayer currently only has the deathmatch and team deathmatch gamemodes, but they're both a lot of fun. Deathmatch is just chaotic killing and I'm sure team deathmatch is a lot better with friends than it is on your own. The maps are full of detail, being big enough to survive and find a weapon, but not too big that you're isolated from the action. It's a shame there are only two gamemodes, but I feel the quality and quantity of the maps make up for that, and I'm looking forward to when they do add different gamemodes in the future.

The singleplayer is better than it was in the mod, there are several significant changes; the new sounds and models are great, the general look is better with various subtle changes, and some major ones too. Even though the game is unfinished, it still has a lot of replay value to it. I've played the mod excessively, yet I'm sure I'll play this newer version many times until the game is completed. So far, there haven't been any game-breaking bugs, the game crashed several times when I first started and there have been a few dodgy textures floating around but they are not frequent enough to be annoying.

Overall, I would recommend this game. It is reasonably priced by today's standards, and there is a lot to do in both the single and the multiplayer, even being unfinished.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa is a great game, with both graphics and gameplay.

It does have a few glitchs, but nothing too much to make the game bad.

However I was disapointed when I found out that the game still dosent have the xen chapters, But that doesnt mean I stop playing.

The games story is as good as ever, and the combat is more flexible and more fast action.

The music is SO GOOD, this game has the best ost because the music only plays when it needs too.
Witch makes it very beautiful.

I also love that they added 1600 x 900 resolution, with it, makes the game look more beautiful.

The voice acting is spot on and the models look AWESOME.

And I didnt expect to LOVE Multiplayer, and character creation!? Woah I didnt expect that!

So all in all, I love this game. And I think its one of the best remakes I played so far

Story: 10/10

Gameplay: 9/10

Music: 10/10

Graphics: 9/10

Voice Acting: 9/10

Multiplayer: 8/10

TOTAL SCORE: 55/100

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is one of the reasons i love the Half-Life community. I hear people say that this game is way too expensive or it's not worth it when you can get the mod for free. I would like to clarify the Black Mesa Dev Team/Crowbar Collective have spent their time and hard earned money to develop a beautiful and atmospheric game for the community and do VALVes job of making a TRUE Half-Life Remake. My personal opinion is that these guys deserve it.... ALOT!!!! Any point during the development phase they could have just canned the project, But they didn't . They wanted to keep their promise (VALVe.... Take note) and continually inform the public and keep posting updates during the 8 year development period. Sure it has its kinks and defects but thats why they released it on Early access, They wanted our say.

So please if you have played the original mod and thougt it was a piece of art.... Buy the game and give the developers the respect and money they deserve.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa is a very ambitious remake of Half-Life in the Source (aka Half-Life 2) engine.  Years ago, I tried the original free release and was impressed by the level design, but found there were a lot of gameplay mechanics that needed to be adjusted, fixed, etc.  I am happy to report that the Steam release is a huge improvement over the original free one, particularly in the combat portions, and is far closer to being a completed" game despite it not currently having the last Xen levels done yet.

Many people online have been complaining that the $20 price is too expensive
date: but when you consider the fact that this group of people have been working very hard for years to make this happen
recommended: you can't help but appreciate all the time and effort they have put into it.  In fact
hoursPlayed: they have actually improved upon many chapters/levels from the original game in many ways and the overall presentation is excellent.\n\nFor a person that has played both HL1 and HL2 too many times to count
voteText: this was just as much fun in its own ways and think you'll dig it too.  I look forward to seeing it completed and fully tweaked
helpfulPercent: no matter how long it takes and wish the team the best of luck in finally being able to reach the finish line."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa, the largely anticipated remake of one of the best first person shooter games of all time, certainly lives up to the standards of its predecessor. It was made by fans of the Half-Life franchise, and it is a very large project indeed. It originally started as a mod of Half-Life 2, but has now grown into a standalone game.

There are two versions of Black Mesa.
BMS 2012 (The mod version)
BMS 2015 (The Steam version)

BMS 2012 was released in 2012, as a mod that required Valve's free Source SDK base 2007 to run. It was a groundbreaking remake of the first Half-Life game's single player campaign, minus the final four chapters. After 8 years in development, it was worth the weight wait.

BMS 2015 was recently released, you guessed it, in 2015, on Steam. This version features updated graphics, new content, new voice acting, and an all new multiplayer experience, featuring free-for-all deathmatch and team deathmatch modes. The final four chapters have yet to be added, and I am very excited for them, as I have heard that they will be packed full of gameplay. People have complained about the $20 price tag, despite the fact that the developers that make up Crowbar Collective have stated long ago that they intended to sell the Steam version.

I am happy with the price, as the developers deserve to earn money for such a jaw-droppingly epic project. People also need to understand that it is in early access, so of course there will be problems that will ultimately be fixed. As a game, Black Mesa is very engaging in the departments of gameplay and story. As a remake, Black Mesa is truly beyond astounding. It reminds me so much of Half-Life, when it comes to the art style, the level design, and the (occasional) humor. The developers have added many nods to the Half-Life storyline that developed after the first game was released. And also, the Gman is as mysterious as ever.

10/10. Amazing.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played the majority of Black Mesa Source before it came to early access, and I'm enjoying playing the current incarnation even more, being that it's more rounded out and has some great (and authentic) multiplayer. Some performance issues aside online, the game is running very smoothly and it is clear that the game is a labour of love by a dedicated team.

My only bone of contention, and it's arguable that I'm perhaps missing the point, is that in some ways the game doesn't quite go far enough in it's vision, or perhaps rather than it is at times inconsistent in it's execution. The approach, obviously, is to recreate, or 're-envision' Half-Life from beginning to end, using modern technology and methods that are more contemporary to gaming post 2000 (or even 2005). The result is a game that is not just visually familiar but one that plays very familiarly, for better and worse. Some of Half-Life's more irritating sections have been altered and streamlined, yet some are curiously left unaltered, issues intact. Something about this inconsistency speaks to the games origins as a mod by a team spread out geographically, with level designers with different ideas of what the game should be like spread out far and wide. The Sector C labs, for instance, have been extended and fleshed out with a great deal more detail, but this is more superficial, whereas the Office Complex unit has been edited and reshaped more substantially, to greater effect. Some of the original chapter's more bland areas are not just visually striking, but contain fresh secrets and nooks and crannies to explore, as well as some surprises, enemy wise. At the very least, the facelift is welcome, but at times it feels like the opportunity to really take the essence of Half-Life and build upon it is underused in favour of remaining faithful.

The game is still in development, of course. Xen is still absent, presumably because it was always going to be the most problematic chapter to rebuild in terms of making it actually enjoyable, this time around (it always was a bizarre end to the original Half-Life, tonally shifting entirely from intense combat to akward platforming mechanics and a really terrible boss fight at the end). I'm hoping the workshop features some other additions that allow other interpretations to be dropped into the single player experience as well as the welcome but predictable multiplayer remakes.

The multiplayer component, whilst suffering from performance issues at the moment (a few days after initial release), is a blast and really does take me back to the LAN party death-match sessions I would indulge in when I was fifteen and sixteen years old. The weapons all feel substantial and impactful, and the map design is first-rate.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access/Pre Zen Update

11hrs for £15 (so far).

Gameplay wise it hasn't changed too much from Half Life 1. So if you liked the original, chances are you'll like this.

There's been a few changes in level designs and I think the weapons have been slightly rebalanced, so don't expect a complete carbon copy of the original. Saying that, I liked most of the changes. Personally, I found some of the platforming sections annoying (as I did in the original - something I would have been happy if they had skipped recreating) and the bloody assassins are real pains, but getting past them gives the same sense of achievement. In that sense I enjoyed the game.

However, the big selling point, and the original point (from what I remember) of the mod, was to recreate Half Life with better graphics. And this is where the developers both succeed and fail. If this had been released a couple of years after Half Life 2, then I wouldn't have any reservations about recommending it. Unfortunately, the engine has aged (not as badly as some mind you), but its obvious that this engine is 11 years old. And it struggles to compete against more recent efforts. Saying that, its obvious that, in certain areas, the developers have put a lot of effort in, and the game looks absolutely amazing. I certainly paused in places to have a look around and enjoy the views. But, at this stage in development, that quality isn't consistent. And that's the problem. Its 2015, and at times, I would be hard pressed to tell the difference between this game and the original 17 year old game (yeah... that's made me feel old).

So its hard to recommend it, but I will. I loved the original, and this game has allowed me to revisit that world, but in a much prettier way.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wonderfully recreation of Half-Life.
Think Half-Life with the engine of Half-Life 2. It's HL better than you remember; I felt like I was playing HL1 for the first time again.
It has the same story as HL1 but beyond that everything has been updated. New textures on EVERYTHING, new voice acting, new scripted events, new ENGINE.
The new textures make gameplay more immersive and the people look more like, well, people. The bullsquid is incredibly terrifying now. The voice acting has been redone and some new dialogue can be heard, especially from the new female scientists (I guess the EO complaints finally caught up with Lambda.)
There are new scripted events for enemy intros that really show off all the work the Crowbar Collective has put into this game. Most levels have been modified in small ways to use puzzle mechanics from 2HL2. Anyone who is a fan of the HL series will enjoy playing game as we wait for the next installmant in the HL franchise.
Pros:
-New Engine!
-HL2 mechanics-set enemies on fire, throw back grenades, crawling zombies
-New textures for EVERYTHING
-Voice acting redone and more dialogue from NPCs, female scientists.
-New enemy intros, attack styles, and sounds
-Most levels updated to feature puzzle mechanics from HL2
-Amazing gameplay!


Cons:
-As of writing this the entire game has not been completed yet; Xen levels not released.
-Some of the levels have ledges big enough to walk around/skip fights i.e. Surface Tension
-On the level Surface Tension" if you travel to the sublevel 'Ordnance Exterior'
date: leave and return you can be stuck in a loop of gameover explosions. Can set you back if you don't save.\n-Enemy AI seems more like NPCs always know where you are even-through walls. i.e. Tanks and Helicopters are always aimed and shooting at you even inside buildings."

Early Access Review

Great job they did in here. First, the texture, graphical and enviromental improvements, such as shadows and advanced lightning system, something that shows up a bit higher than Source engine normal standards, making you notice how well enhanced this basic engine is from its original version. Everything is so refined at its best.
Second to mention, weapons. They passed through a large model modification (Mp5, the Glock, Magnum, Gauss Gun). But the shotgun and some others only had an animation readjust, but still really better than the Mod version. In the mod version the shotgun sounded. just. ♥♥♥♥♥♥
In this version they also changed the H.E.C.U voice acting, which was pretty ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as hell in the mod version. Thank god that is replaced now, by some more commando-like voice acting, bringing the feeling of your character fighting real enemies.
Well, there's a lot more to tell about readjustments and enhancements, find it out by yourself, this is only the beginning!
My focus?. Great Job. I enjoyed it from the start to the last  part the game. Still Waiting for xen!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After first hearing about this project in 2007 I had given up on all hope of seeing it come to fruition some years ago, but after finally seeing that it was up on Steam I immediately dropped the money and tried it out. It was money well spent, to say the least.

I feel like I've played Half-Life for the first time again. The developers have gone to great lengths to make the Black Mesa research facility feel more like an actual research facility. There's an innumerable amount little details that have been added that really make the facility feel more human and alive.

I look forward to getting to see the finished product (Xen especially) and I have yet to be disappointed with this excellent re-imagining of one of video gamings crown jewels.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An absolutely amazing remake of the original Half-Life game. The soundtrack, voice acting, combat, characters/enemy's and places in the game is amazing, beautiful and doesn't remove those awesome feelings you get as you did in Half-Life, its smooth and feels great to walk/run around and shoot. The enemy's in this game is not easy to kill (it depends on what difficulty level you are on) and that will give you a challenge through out the campain. Everything fits perfect in the remake and doesn't disappoint at all. If you have ever played Half-Life and likes it or love it then i recommend this 100% to you. The multiplayer is also lots of fun and feels like those classic deathmatch you love or loved. The Developers have been working so much on this game for around 10 years and its worth the money.

First off, I just want to clarify that this Steam version has massively been improved, cause it's not EXACTLY the same as the free mod, it actually feels much more complete now, new weapon animations and sounds, more authentic touches, such as the HEV start-up thingy (which was pretty damn cool, not even Valve thought about doing that!). You're nearly at the point where a great game is perfect!

So in short, buy it now, and become a mute, badass, goatee bearded, HEV donning physicist today!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

1. This is a great game, and not just a recreation of Half Life. Anyone who hasn't played Half Life might want to play that first, but if not you could jump into this and still have a great time.
2. Multiplayer: It's not flawless, but its still fun for a couple of hours.
3. Most amount of work I've seen put into a community-made game recently that I've bothered to play.
4. Play the mod if you still aren't sure about buying the full game, but I was willing to get the full version just because of how much I enjoyed the original mod and wanted to see more happen to it.

Anyways, I love the Half Life series, and this game is an excellent nostalgic, yet refreshing experience of headcrab bashing, scientist whining, puzzle-solving fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This has to be one of the most fun games i've played in a while!

The single player is one heck of a ride. I've finished the first Half Life 3 times (HL3 confirmed, lol jk) and I never had the feeling that I was wasting my time playing this single player, since it is so well made. From the level design to the monsters and visuals, everything is refined and looking great!

The multi player is also a nice addition. If you like some arena style shooters (quake-like), than this is the game for you!

Well worth its $20 pricetag!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While there are differences between Halflife 1 and Black Mesa, as far as any fan of Halflife 1 will be concerned, Black Mesa IS Halflife 1 with modern graphics and a modern physics engine.  I will also recommend listening to the conversations prior to the 'incident' as some conversations are very meta arguments about recreating something old for modern audiences.

Square Enix could make a mint if they gave FF7 the treatment that Black Mesa gives Halflife.

Well done, devs, well done.

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Better than the original yet faithful to the spirit - this is what Valve probably wanted Half-Life to be.  This game was a joy to play - I actually loved being able to roam a huge base again, but in very high resolution and with all the little touches like coffee cups and decent looking instrumentation and damaged areas.  Very realistic.  The game presented lots of interesting and relevant puzzles and challenges yet it is very intuitive - you solve things the way you really would if you were in the situation.  No bugs - excellent performance - outstanding graphic realism - smart enemies.

Fantastic job - MORE PLEASE!!!!!  I'd love to be able to roam a starship or a planetary base or an ocean base - these types of games are just a lot of fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just as the initial mod release improved upon the original Half-Life, this stand-alone version improves upon the mod. There are new animations, new weapon models, better NPC voices, and numerous tweaks to the AI. The original mod version is still available for free. Just keep in mind that the mod version does not have the aforementioned tweaks.

I just fininished the single player portion, and I enjoyed it every bit as much as I did when I played the original mod version back in 2012. My only real complaint concerns the AI tweaks. The HECU soldiers in the original mod had deadly accuracy and split-second reaction times, causing firefights with them to feel extremely unfair. This has been fixed for the Steam release. Unfortunately, the soldiers are now too dumb, instead of being too smart. Sometimes they charge blindy at you with no sense of self-preservation, and other times they just stand there without even bothering to shoot back. This issue is even more noticeable with the Vortigaunts. I would like to see the AI tweaked a bit further.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Black Mesa is a great game, I played through the mod many times and I bought this version mainly for the multiplayer, which did not disappoint.

The multiplayer currently only has the deathmatch and team deathmatch gamemodes, but they're both a lot of fun. Deathmatch is just chaotic killing and I'm sure team deathmatch is a lot better with friends than it is on your own. The maps are full of detail, being big enough to survive and find a weapon, but not too big that you're isolated from the action. It's a shame there are only two gamemodes, but I feel the quality and quantity of the maps make up for that, and I'm looking forward to when they do add different gamemodes in the future.

The singleplayer is better than it was in the mod, there are several significant changes; the new sounds and models are great, the general look is better with various subtle changes, and some major ones too. Even though the game is unfinished, it still has a lot of replay value to it. I've played the mod excessively, yet I'm sure I'll play this newer version many times until the game is completed. So far, there haven't been any game-breaking bugs, the game crashed several times when I first started and there have been a few dodgy textures floating around but they are not frequent enough to be annoying.

Overall, I would recommend this game. It is reasonably priced by today's standards, and there is a lot to do in both the single and the multiplayer, even being unfinished.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most people expect a replica of Half Life 1 - and hence compare this mod very critically with Half Life 1. If you think that way as well you might get disappointed. As some reviews already pointed out this is not exactly Half Life 1. It follows the general story line and sticks to the original map layouts wherever sensible and possible. But it still brings its own style. And as soon as you accept that this is a mod with its own style it's actually quite enjoyable.

One thing I (as a casual player) did not like is the difficulty which is solely generated by raising the number of enemies significantly (and - in my opinion - unnecessarily). Half Life (all of it) for me is first and foremost about the story telling. And when you play through HL2 and its two episodes with commentary on you really get a feel of the level in which that was done intentionally by Valve. This is where raw numbers of enemies don't make sense. A good balance does.

Generally: Play it. It's worth it! Wait for the Xen levels if you want a full game, this one still stops at the jump to Xen.

Early Access Review

Black Mesa is a great game, with both graphics and gameplay.

It does have a few glitchs, but nothing too much to make the game bad.

However I was disapointed when I found out that the game still dosent have the xen chapters, But that doesnt mean I stop playing.

The games story is as good as ever, and the combat is more flexible and more fast action.

The music is SO GOOD, this game has the best ost because the music only plays when it needs too.
Witch makes it very beautiful.

I also love that they added 1600 x 900 resolution, with it, makes the game look more beautiful.

The voice acting is spot on and the models look AWESOME.

And I didnt expect to LOVE Multiplayer, and character creation!? Woah I didnt expect that!

So all in all, I love this game. And I think its one of the best remakes I played so far

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, let me say that I am 100% against Steam cashing in on user content (mods)...
That being said, Black Mesa is above and beyond what I believe is a mod. Yes, it's based on Valve's existing game, but it stops there. This is not an HD texture reskin. I believe this to be a top-down remake (textures, models, animations).

I was amazed at how well this was put tothether and how well it ran on my mobile card (780m, 175-299fps).

If you liked Half-Life, this one is a no-brainer.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now here is a solid dose of old school thinking man's shooting, the way games should be. Firstly (admittedly because for some reason half life 2 engine doesnt like my laptop) load times are terrible. But when you get there... wow. Black mesa, not just the way you remember it, but the way you imagined it... the way it would have been.

The old fashioined puzzles that are still from the original have been augmented by puzzles thattake advantage of the newer engine. Stunning. Still nothing more delightful than doing away with the tentacles in blast pit. Or watching the rocket launch... awesome.

The new sound track is great, emotive and appropriate to the setting. The look of the aliens is entirely convincing, and you really believe that the alien slaves are just fighting because they have been ordered to, so they dont clash too much with their role in the second half life. I particularly like the Houndeyes, which i missed a little in the sequel. And seriously the bullsquid is just as horrifying as the first time round, with more convinving chemical spit, which glows and sticks to your hands and weapon most beautifully.

This is a GREAT re working of a classic. But there are at least 2 reasons why it needs work. 1; AI of army and assassins is bloody atrocious, and occasionally aliens will ignore you until you shoot at them. Head crabs appear to move towards some sort of anchor point" before trying to attack again
date: rather than continuously attacking. 2: Although i love the use of the modern engine for some puzzles
recommended: i think it could have been used more. Flares being used instead of a crowbar for killing the first few zombies GREAT
